questiontext.text:
Question 3 — First-Order Circuit Analysis Using Laplace Transforms (13 pts)

Consider the circuit shown below. At \(t = 0\), a DC voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\) is applied as a step input \(V_s \cdot u(t)\). The circuit contains resistors \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\Omega\), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\Omega\), \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\Omega\), and an inductor \(L = {@L@}\;\text{H}\). Assume zero initial conditions.

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v1_rl_step.svg]

Note: Express numerical answers to 3 significant figures. Scientific notation is accepted (e.g., 2.50*10^3 or 2.50E3).

Part A (2 pts)

When transforming this circuit to the s-domain with zero initial conditions, what is the s-domain impedance of the inductor \(L\)?

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

  • (a) \(sL\)
  • (b) \(\dfrac{1}{sL}\)
  • (c) \(\dfrac{L}{s}\)
  • (d) \(s^2 L\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts)

Determine the equivalent resistance \(R_\text{eq}\) that the inductor \(L\) "sees" looking back into the rest of the circuit from its terminals (with the voltage source replaced by its internal impedance).

Give your answer in ohms to 3 significant figures.

\(R_\text{eq} = \) [[input:ansB]] \(\Omega\) [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts)

Using your result from Part B, compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this circuit.

Give your answer in seconds to 3 significant figures.

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Physical Interpretation (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • What is the inductor current at \(t = 0^+\)? What is it as \(t \to \infty\)? Justify both using circuit analysis or the s-domain.
  • Explain the physical meaning of the time constant \(\tau\) you computed. What happens to the current at \(t = \tau\)?

[[input:ansD]] [[validation:ansD]]

generalfeedback.text:
Solution

Part A: With zero initial conditions, an inductor \(L\) in the s-domain is represented by impedance \(Z_L = sL\). Answer: (a).

Part B: To find the equivalent resistance seen by L, replace Vs with a short circuit. Looking from the L terminals (node B to ground): R3 is in series with the parallel combination R1‖R2. \[R_\text{eq} = R_3 + \frac{R_1 R_2}{R_1 + R_2} = {@R3@} + \frac{{@R1@} \cdot {@R2@}}{{@R1@} + {@R2@}} = {@Req@}\;\Omega\]

Part C: \(\tau = L / R_\text{eq} = {@L@} / {@Req@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • At \(t=0^+\), \(i_L = 0\) because an inductor opposes instantaneous changes in current (zero initial conditions).
  • As \(t\to\infty\), the inductor acts as a short circuit. The Thevenin voltage at node B is \(V_\text{th} = V_s \cdot R_2/(R_1+R_2) = {@Vth@}\;\text{V}\). The steady-state current is \(i_L(\infty) = V_\text{th}/R_\text{eq} = {@Isteady@}\;\text{A}\).
  • The time constant \(\tau = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\) is the time at which the current reaches approximately 63.2% of its final value. After \(5\tau\), the current is within 1% of steady state.

questiontext.text:
Question 3 — First-Order Circuit Analysis Using Laplace Transforms (13 pts)

Consider the circuit shown below. At \(t = 0\), a DC voltage source \(V_s = {@Vs@}\;\text{V}\) is applied as a step input \(V_s \cdot u(t)\). The circuit contains resistors \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\Omega\), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\Omega\), \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\Omega\), \(R_4 = {@R4@}\;\Omega\), and a capacitor \(C = {@Cval@}\;\text{F}\). Assume zero initial conditions.

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v2_rc_step.svg]

Note: Express numerical answers to 3 significant figures. Scientific notation is accepted (e.g., 2.50*10^3 or 2.50E3).

Part A (2 pts)

When transforming this circuit to the s-domain with zero initial conditions, what is the s-domain impedance of the capacitor \(C\)?

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

  • (a) \(sC\)
  • (b) \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\)
  • (c) \(\dfrac{C}{s}\)
  • (d) \(\dfrac{s}{C}\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts)

Determine the equivalent resistance \(R_\text{eq}\) that the capacitor \(C\) "sees" looking out from its terminals into the rest of the circuit (with the voltage source replaced by its internal impedance).

Give your answer in ohms to 3 significant figures.

\(R_\text{eq} = \) [[input:ansB]] \(\Omega\) [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts)

Using your result from Part B, compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this circuit.

Give your answer in seconds to 3 significant figures.

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Physical Interpretation (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • What is the voltage across the capacitor at \(t = 0^+\)? What is it as \(t \to \infty\)? Justify both answers.
  • Explain the physical meaning of the time constant \(\tau\) you computed. At \(t = \tau\), what fraction of the final voltage has the capacitor reached?

[[input:ansD]] [[validation:ansD]]

generalfeedback.text:
Solution

Part A: With zero initial conditions, a capacitor \(C\) in the s-domain has impedance \(Z_C = 1/(sC)\). Answer: (b).

Part B: Remove C and short the voltage source. From the A-side terminal: R1‖R2. From the B-side terminal: R3‖R4. Since these are in series: \[R_\text{eq} = \frac{R_1 R_2}{R_1+R_2} + \frac{R_3 R_4}{R_3+R_4} = {@Req@}\;\Omega\]

Part C: \(\tau = R_\text{eq} \cdot C = {@Req@} \times {@Cval@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • At \(t=0^+\), \(v_C = 0\) because a capacitor opposes instantaneous changes in voltage (zero initial conditions).
  • As \(t\to\infty\), the capacitor is fully charged and no current flows through it. The Thevenin voltage is \(V_\text{th} = V_s \cdot R_2/(R_1+R_2) = {@Vth@}\;\text{V}\) (only the A-side divider contributes since no current flows through R3/R4 at steady state).
  • At \(t = \tau\), the capacitor has reached approximately 63.2% of its final voltage (\(1-e^{-1}\)).

questionnote.text: V2 RC Step Bridge: Vs={@Vs@}, R1={@R1@}, R2={@R2@}, R3={@R3@}, R4={@R4@}, C={@Cval@}, Req={@Req@}, tau={@tau@}

questiontext.text:
Question 3 — First-Order Circuit Analysis Using Laplace Transforms (13 pts)

In the circuit shown below, an inductor \(L = {@L@}\;\text{H}\) carries an initial current \(I_0 = {@I0@}\;\text{A}\) at \(t = 0\). At \(t = 0\), the inductor is connected to the resistor network consisting of \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\Omega\), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\Omega\), \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\Omega\), and \(R_4 = {@R4@}\;\Omega\). There is no external source.

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v3_rl_natural.svg]

Note: Express numerical answers to 3 significant figures. Scientific notation is accepted (e.g., 2.50*10^3 or 2.50E3).

Part A (2 pts)

In the s-domain, how is an inductor \(L\) with a nonzero initial current \(I_0\) modeled?

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

  • (a) Impedance \(sL\) only
  • (b) Impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(LI_0\)
  • (c) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sL}\) in parallel with a current source \(I_0/s\)
  • (d) Impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(I_0/s\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts)

Determine the equivalent resistance \(R_\text{eq}\) that the inductor "sees" looking into the resistor network from its terminals.

Give your answer in ohms to 3 significant figures.

\(R_\text{eq} = \) [[input:ansB]] \(\Omega\) [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts)

Using your result from Part B, compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this circuit.

Give your answer in seconds to 3 significant figures.

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Physical Interpretation (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • What is the inductor current at \(t = 0^+\)? What is it as \(t \to \infty\)? Justify both answers.
  • The initial energy stored in the inductor is \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}LI_0^2\). Where does this energy go? Explain how it is distributed among the resistors in the network.

[[input:ansD]] [[validation:ansD]]

generalfeedback.text:
Solution

Part A: An inductor with initial current \(I_0\) is modeled as impedance \(sL\) in series with a voltage source \(LI_0\). This arises from \(\mathcal{L}\{L\,di/dt\} = sL \cdot I(s) - LI_0\). Answer: (b).

Part B: Looking from the inductor terminals (node X to ground): R4 is directly from X to ground. In parallel with that path, R1 goes from X to node A, where R2 and R3 are both connected to ground (R2‖R3). So: \[R_\text{eq} = R_4 \;\|\; \left[R_1 + (R_2 \| R_3)\right] = R_4 \;\|\; \left[R_1 + \frac{R_2 R_3}{R_2+R_3}\right] = {@Req@}\;\Omega\]

Part C: \(\tau = L / R_\text{eq} = {@L@} / {@Req@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • At \(t=0^+\), \(i_L = I_0 = {@I0@}\;\text{A}\) because an inductor opposes instantaneous changes in current.
  • As \(t\to\infty\), \(i_L = 0\) because there is no source to sustain the current.
  • The stored energy \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}({@L@})({@I0@})^2 = {@W0@}\;\text{J}\) is entirely dissipated as heat in the four resistors. The energy splits among R1, R2, R3, and R4 according to the current distribution through each path.

questionnote.text: V3 RL Natural Network: I0={@I0@}, R1={@R1@}, R2={@R2@}, R3={@R3@}, R4={@R4@}, L={@L@}, Req={@Req@}, tau={@tau@}

questiontext.text:
Question 3 — First-Order Circuit Analysis Using Laplace Transforms (13 pts)

In the circuit shown below, a capacitor \(C = {@Cval@}\;\text{F}\) is initially charged to a voltage \(V_0 = {@V0@}\;\text{V}\). At \(t = 0\), the capacitor is connected to the resistor network consisting of \(R_1 = {@R1@}\;\Omega\), \(R_2 = {@R2@}\;\Omega\), \(R_3 = {@R3@}\;\Omega\), and \(R_4 = {@R4@}\;\Omega\). There is no external source.

[INSERT DIAGRAM: diagrams/q3/q3_v4_rc_natural.svg]

Note: Express numerical answers to 3 significant figures. Scientific notation is accepted (e.g., 2.50*10^3 or 2.50E3).

Part A (2 pts)

In the s-domain, how is a capacitor \(C\) with an initial voltage \(V_0\) modeled?

[[input:ansA]] [[validation:ansA]]

  • (a) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) only
  • (b) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in series with a voltage source \(\dfrac{V_0}{s}\)
  • (c) Impedance \(sC\) in series with a voltage source \(V_0 \cdot s\)
  • (d) Impedance \(\dfrac{1}{sC}\) in parallel with a current source \(\dfrac{V_0}{R_1}\)

Enter the letter of your choice: a, b, c, or d.

[[feedback:prtA]]

Part B (4 pts)

Determine the equivalent resistance \(R_\text{eq}\) that the capacitor "sees" looking into the resistor network from its terminals.

Give your answer in ohms to 3 significant figures.

\(R_\text{eq} = \) [[input:ansB]] \(\Omega\) [[validation:ansB]]

[[feedback:prtB]]

Part C (4 pts)

Using your result from Part B, compute the time constant \(\tau\) of this circuit.

Give your answer in seconds to 3 significant figures.

\(\tau = \) [[input:ansC]] seconds [[validation:ansC]]

[[feedback:prtC]]

Part D (3 pts) — Physical Interpretation (Essay)

Answer the following:

  • What is the capacitor voltage at \(t = 0^+\)? What is it as \(t \to \infty\)? Justify both answers.
  • The initial energy stored in the capacitor is \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}CV_0^2\). Where does this energy go? Explain how it is distributed among the resistors in the network.

[[input:ansD]] [[validation:ansD]]

generalfeedback.text:
Solution

Part A: A capacitor with initial voltage \(V_0\) is modeled as impedance \(1/(sC)\) in series with a voltage source \(V_0/s\). This arises from \(V_C(s) = \frac{1}{sC}I(s) + \frac{V_0}{s}\). Answer: (b).

Part B: Looking from the capacitor terminals (node X to ground): R1 goes from X to node A. From node A, there are two paths to ground: R3 directly, and R2+R4 in series through node B. So: \[R_\text{eq} = R_1 + R_3 \;\|\; (R_2 + R_4) = R_1 + \frac{R_3(R_2+R_4)}{R_3+R_2+R_4} = {@Req@}\;\Omega\]

Part C: \(\tau = R_\text{eq} \cdot C = {@Req@} \times {@Cval@} = {@tau@}\;\text{s}\).

Part D:

  • At \(t=0^+\), \(v_C = V_0 = {@V0@}\;\text{V}\) because a capacitor opposes instantaneous changes in voltage.
  • As \(t\to\infty\), \(v_C = 0\) because there is no source to maintain the voltage and all energy is dissipated.
  • The stored energy \(W_0 = \frac{1}{2}({@Cval@})({@V0@})^2 = {@W0@}\;\text{J}\) is entirely dissipated as heat in the four resistors. The distribution depends on the current paths: more energy goes to resistors carrying more current.

questionnote.text: V4 RC Natural Network: V0={@V0@}, R1={@R1@}, R2={@R2@}, R3={@R3@}, R4={@R4@}, C={@Cval@}, Req={@Req@}, tau={@tau@}
